name: Lesson 5 dependency detection
body:
The dependency detection of data profiling includes keys and unique column combinations(Sect. 5.1), functional dependencies (Sect. 5.2), inclusion
dependencies (Sect. 5.3), and other types of dependencies
that are relevant to data profiling (Sect. 5.4).

![Fig. 2 Power lattice for the example Table 4](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/FengtingSun/Third-Year-Project/Pictures/lesson%205%20pic.png)

***

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(DT)
library(data.table)
library(yaml)
DT = data.table(First = c("Max", "Eve", "Eve", "Max"), 
                Last = c("Payne", "Smith", "Payne", "Payne"),
                Age = c("32", "24", "24", "24"),
                Phone = c("1234", "5432", "3333", "3333"))
```

```{r}
datatable(DT)
```

***

### 5.1 Unique column combinations and keys
**Definition 1** *(Unique)* A column combination X ⊆ R is a unique, iff ∀ri , r j ∈ r, i 	= j : ri [X] 	= r j [X].

**Definition 2 ** *(Non-unique)* A column combination X ⊆ R is a non-unique, iff ∃ri , r j ∈ r, i 	= j : ri [X] = r j [X]


**Definition 3** *(MinimalUnique)* Acolumn combination X ⊆ R is a minimal unique, iff ∀X' ⊂ X : X' is a non-unique.

**Definition 4** *(Maximal Non-Unique)* A column combination X ⊆ R is a maximal non-unique, iff ∀X' ⊃ X : X' is a unique.
